etymologies: Old English wel(l), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch wel and German wohl; probably also to the verb will. Vowel lengthening in Middle English gave rise to the current Scots form weel

notes.text: The adverb well is often used in combination with past participles to form compound adjectives: well-adjusted, well-intentioned, well-known, and so on. As far as hyphenation is concerned, there are three general rules: (1) if the compound adjective is placed before the noun (i.e., in the attributive position), it should be hyphenated (a well-intentioned remark); (2) if the compound adjective is preceded by an adverb (much, very, surprisingly, etc.), the compound adjective is open (a thoroughly well prepared student); (3) if the compound adjective is placed after the noun or verb (i.e., in the predicate position), it may, but need not, be hyphenated (her remark was well-intentioned or her remark was well intentioned). Likewise, other, similar compounds with better, best, ill, little, lesser, least, etc., are hyphenated before the noun (a little-known author), often open after a noun or verb (the author was little known), and open if modified by an adverb (a very little known author).
On uses of well and good, see good

definitions: in a good or satisfactory way

examples.text: the whole team played well

definitions: in a way that is appropriate to the facts or circumstances

examples.text: you did well to come and tell me
a well-timed exit

shortDefinitions: in way that is appropriate to facts or circumstances

definitions: so as to have a fortunate outcome

examples.text: his campaign did not go well

shortDefinitions: so as to have fortunate outcome

definitions: in a kind way

examples.text: the animals will remain loyal to humans if treated well

definitions: with praise or approval

examples.text: people spoke well of him
the film was quite well reviewed at the time

definitions: with equanimity

examples.text: she took it very well, all things considered

definitions: profitably; advantageously

examples.text: she would marry well or not at all

definitions: in a condition of prosperity or comfort

examples.text: they lived well and were generous with their money

shortDefinitions: in condition of prosperity or comfort

definitions: luckily; opportunely

examples.text: hail fellow, well met

definitions: in a thorough manner

examples.text: add the mustard and lemon juice and mix well

definitions: to a great extent or degree (often used for emphasis)

examples.text: the visit had been planned well in advance
a well-loved mother

definitions: intimately; closely

examples.text: he knew my father very well

definitions: very; extremely

examples.text: he was well out of order

definitions: used as an intensifier

examples.text: I should damn well hope so

definitions: very probably; in all likelihood

examples.text: being short of breath may well be the first sign of asthma

definitions: without difficulty

examples.text: she could well afford to pay for the reception herself

definitions: with good reason

examples.text: “What are we doing here?” “You may well ask.”

notes.text: The adverb well is often used in combination with past participles to form compound adjectives: well-adjusted, well-intentioned, well-known, and so on. As far as hyphenation is concerned, there are three general rules: (1) if the compound adjective is placed before the noun (i.e., in the attributive position), it should be hyphenated (a well-intentioned remark); (2) if the compound adjective is preceded by an adverb (much, very, surprisingly, etc.), the compound adjective is open (a thoroughly well prepared student); (3) if the compound adjective is placed after the noun or verb (i.e., in the predicate position), it may, but need not, be hyphenated (her remark was well-intentioned or her remark was well intentioned). Likewise, other, similar compounds with better, best, ill, little, lesser, least, etc., are hyphenated before the noun (a little-known author), often open after a noun or verb (the author was little known), and open if modified by an adverb (a very little known author).
On uses of well and good, see good

definitions: in good health; free or recovered from illness

examples.text: I don't feel very well
it would be some time before Sarah was completely well
he was not a well man

definitions: in a satisfactory state or position

examples.text: all is not well in her ideal-looking town

definitions: sensible; advisable

examples.text: it would be well to know just what this suggestion entails

notes.text: The adverb well is often used in combination with past participles to form compound adjectives: well-adjusted, well-intentioned, well-known, and so on. As far as hyphenation is concerned, there are three general rules: (1) if the compound adjective is placed before the noun (i.e., in the attributive position), it should be hyphenated (a well-intentioned remark); (2) if the compound adjective is preceded by an adverb (much, very, surprisingly, etc.), the compound adjective is open (a thoroughly well prepared student); (3) if the compound adjective is placed after the noun or verb (i.e., in the predicate position), it may, but need not, be hyphenated (her remark was well-intentioned or her remark was well intentioned). Likewise, other, similar compounds with better, best, ill, little, lesser, least, etc., are hyphenated before the noun (a little-known author), often open after a noun or verb (the author was little known), and open if modified by an adverb (a very little known author).
On uses of well and good, see good

definitions: used to express a range of emotions including surprise, anger, resignation, or relief

examples.text: Well, really! The manners of some people!

shortDefinitions: used to express range of emotions including surprise, anger or relief

definitions: used when pausing to consider one's next words

examples.text: well, I suppose I could fit you in at 3:45

shortDefinitions: used when pausing to consider one's next words, to mark resumption or end of conversation

definitions: used to express agreement or acceptance, often in a qualified or slightly reluctant way

examples.text: well, all right, but be quick

shortDefinitions: used to express agreement or acceptance, often in qualified or slightly reluctant way

definitions: used to introduce the resumption of a narrative or a change of subject.
shortDefinitions: used to introduce resumption of narrative or change of subject

definitions: used to mark the end of a conversation or activity

examples.text: well, cheers, Tom—I must run

shortDefinitions: used to mark end of conversation or activity

definitions: used to indicate that one is waiting for an answer or explanation from someone

examples.text: Well? You promised to tell me all about it

shortDefinitions: used to indicate that one is waiting for answer or explanation from someone

etymologies: Old English wella, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch wel and German Welle ‘a wave’

definitions: a shaft sunk into the ground to obtain water, oil, or gas.
shortDefinitions: shaft sunk into ground to obtain water or gas

definitions: a water spring or fountain.
(in place names) a place where there are mineral springs

examples.text: Tunbridge Wells

shortDefinitions: place where there are mineral springs

definitions: a depression made to hold liquid

examples.text: put the flour on a flat surface and make a well to hold the eggs

definitions: a plentiful source or supply

examples.text: she could feel a deep well of sympathy and compassion

definitions: an enclosed space in the middle of a building, giving room for stairs or an elevator, or to allow light or ventilation.
shortDefinitions: enclosed space in middle of building, giving room for stairs or lift

definitions: the place in a court of law where the clerks and ushers sit.
shortDefinitions: place in law court where clerks and ushers sit

definitions: a shelf beneath the counter of a bar on which bottles of liquor are stored within easy reach of the bartender

examples.text: you would have never heard of the label of the gin in the well in average bars

crossReferenceMarkers: Compare with call (sense 10 of the noun)
definitions: denoting or made with the relatively inexpensive brands of liquor stored in the well of a bar.

examples.text: happy hour is from 4 to 7 p.m. weekdays, with $4 well drinks and draft beers
three shots of well tequila

shortDefinitions: denoting or made with relatively inexpensive brands of alcohol

definitions: a region of minimum potential

examples.text: a gravity well

definitions: (of a liquid) rise to the surface and spill or be about to spill

examples.text: tears were beginning to well in her eyes

shortDefinitions: rise up to surface and spill or be about to spill

definitions: (of an emotion) arise and become more intense

examples.text: all the old bitterness began to well up inside her again
